# Domestic Politics

## Strengthening of state control

::: incremental
-   The state has full control over the media and press ^[“Government and Society,” Encyclopædia Britannica (Encyclopædia Britannica, inc.), accessed January 18, 2023, https://www.britannica.com/place/Russia/Government-and-society.]

-   All Western and anti-Putin rhetoric is stifled

-   Criticism against the Kremlin is censored
:::

## Perestroika

::: incremental
-   The restructuring of the social and economic status quo towards a free market based society ^[“The Gorbachev Era: Perestroika and Glasnost,” Encyclopædia Britannica (Encyclopædia Britannica, inc.), accessed January 18, 2023, https://www.britannica.com/place/Russia/The-Gorbachev-era-perestroika-and-glasnost.]
-   Initiated by Gorbachev in 1985
-   Failed once Putin took over
:::

![](images/image-810274174.png){width="30%"}

# Economics

## After the fall of the USSR

::: incremental
-   Russia dramatically reduced the state's role in economic development^[Sputnik International, “Russia's Economy under Vladimir Putin: Achievements and Failures,” Sputnik International (Sputnik International feedback@sputniknews.com+74956456601MIA „Rosiya Segodnya" 25260, March 1, 2008), https://sputniknews.com/20080301/100381963.html.]
    -   Opened the Russian economy to foreign influence and privatization, especially in the oil sectors
-   Russia's GDP increased by 50% following an economic depression in 1998
:::

![](images/image-1310044862.png)

## Economic Reform

::: incremental
-   Boris Yeltsin had four main pillars to improve the Russian economy:^[Mark Kesselman, Joel Krieger, and William A. Joseph, Introduction to Comparative Politics: Political Challenges and Changing Agendas, 7th ed. (Boston, MA: Cengage Learning, 2016), 274-277.]
    -   Lifting price controls
    -   Encouraging privatization and entrepreneurship
    -   Privatizing state-owned sectors
    -   Opening the economy to international influences (such as investments from the International Monetary Fund)
:::

![](images/50cent.png){width="65%"}

## Economy Today

::: incremental
-   Foreign trade has shifted towards the EU
    -   Trading minerals in exchange for machinery and transport equipment
-   Russia's economic freedom score is 56.1, making it the 113th freest economy^[“GDP (Current US$) - Russian Federation,” Data, accessed January 18, 2023, https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.MKTP.CD?locations=RU.]
:::

![](images/image-563993961.png)

# Foreign Affairs

## The desire to be self sufficient
::: incremental
-   Assertive policies
-   Seeking a great power role in the world
-   Lessen the effect of globalization^[Olga Oliker et al., “What Explains Russia's Annexation of Crimea?,” RAND Corporation, September 22, 2015, https://www.rand.org/pubs/perspectives/PE144.html.]
:::
![](images/image-1301811267.png){width="447"}

## Extending Russian influence
::: incremental
-   Buffer states
-   Improve economic standing^[“Russian Foreign Policy,” Russian Foreign Policy | Center for Strategic and International Studies, February 2, 2016, https://www.csis.org/programs/russia-and-eurasia-program/archives/russian-foreign-policy.]
-   Security
:::

![](images/change.png){width="80%"}

## Competition with the United States
::: incremental
-   Believed Western integration would hurt Russia
-   Implemented a bipartisan approach^[Robert Legvold James Collins, “Russia and Its Neighbors,” Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, accessed January 18, 2023, https://carnegieendowment.org/2009/02/24/russia-and-its-neighbors-event-1266.]

![](images/competition.jpg)
:::
